body:
### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.

Follow-up to #4758 - Numpy also supports "generalized ufuncs". The idea is that arrays of different dimensionality can be combined in predictable ways. For example a function might reduce a 1D array and a scalar to a scalar (and then Numpy would allow this to work automatically on a 2D array and a 1D array

```cython
@ufunc(...) # possible some extra info needs to go here
cdef double f(double[:] x, double y):
    pass
```


### Describe the solution you'd like.

We could extend the infrastructure that exists for standard ufuncs to support this too.

### Describe alternatives you've considered.

The tricky bit of this is handling cases where the *output* array is multi-dimensional. The solution I've used for `ufunc` or returning the type (or a ctuple) won't work or will require a lot of unnecessary allocation. I'd probably be easier to pass in the parameters to be outputted:

```
cdef void f(double [:] x, double y, double [:] out_1, double *out_2):
```
(in this version I'm considering treating all parameters with a name starting with `out` as output parameters. Note that scalars outputs need to be pointers).

Or

```
cdef void g(double [:] x, double y, *, double[:] ret1, double *ret2):
```
(this version proposes using `*` to separate input and output parameters, which would require a parser change)

I haven't got a good solution for this yet, and none of the solutions really handle scalar pyobjects.

### Additional context

_No response_

comment_data.body: I've assigned a 3.1 milestone, not because it has to be in 3.1, but because I think it shouldn't be in 3.0

[GUfuncs require a signature](https://numpy.org/doc/stable/reference/c-api/generalized-ufuncs.html#details-of-signature), such as `(m?,n),(n,p?)->(m?,p?)` for `np.matmul`, which you could parse to check which function arguments would be inputs and which outputs.  This would be a required argument passed to a dedicated gufunc decorator, or perhaps the presence or absence of the signature would tell Cython whether to generate a standard UFunc or a generalized UFunc.  I don't think you can avoid requiring the signature unless you come up with another way to say which axes of which arguments should be the same length and how those affect the output.

Re: the allocation concern: I like the idea of passing the output arrays as arguments, it saves me from having to work out how to allocate memory that will last past the end of the function, since I've had to look that up every time I needed to do so.

There's also functionality to [determine the length of output dimensions not equal to input dimensions](https://numpy.org/doc/stable/reference/c-api/generalized-ufuncs.html#customizing-core-dimension-size-processing), which could be a useful argument to the ufunc/gufunc decorator, but is perhaps best left for a follow-up, rather than the initial implementation.

Hey @da-woods, @DWesl,
I have given implementing a `@cython.gufunc` decorator a shot. See https://github.com/jan-david-fischbach/cython/tree/gufunc-decorator

> [!WARNING]
> As the cython codebase is rather large (and I am fairly unfamiliar with it) I used copilot to help me with some aspects - in particular 
> 1. handling named dimensions in the signatures
> 2. extending the pyx templates to handle passing pointers etc.
> 3. increasing test coverage for named dimensions
> 4. and more
> I have thoroughly checked all suggestions.

## Conceptual Details
As sugested by @DWesl I based the implementation largely on specifying the function signature for example as:
```python
@cython.gufunc("(m,n),(n,p)->(m,p)")
```
for a matrix matrix product. In the function signature the arguments are ordered as `(*input, *output, *named_dimensions)`.
- Inputs are passed in as scalars for "()" and as pointers for array-valued arguments e.g. "(m,n)"
- Outputs are always passed as pointers to make a unified way of retrieval possible. To return a scalar one has to assign `out[0]=scalar`. Multiple outputs are permitted
- If the signature contains named dimensions `numpy` provides the size of these at runtime. They are passed to the decorated function in the order in which they first appear. I.e. for the signature above it would be `cnp.npy_intp m, cnp.npy_intp n, cnp.npy_intp p`.

At compile time it is asserted, that the number of arguments the decorated function expects conforms to the expected number of arguments based on the given signature.

In summary an example function could look like this:
``` python
@cython.gufunc("(m,n),(n,p)->(m,p)")
cdef void matmat(double* a, double* b, double* out, cnp.npy_intp m, cnp.npy_intp n, cnp.npy_intp p):
    """Matrix-matrix multiplication"""
    cdef cnp.npy_intp ii, jj, kk
    # Initialize output
    for ii in range(m):
        for jj in range(p):
            out[ii * p + jj] = 0
    # Compute matrix multiplication
    for ii in range(m):
        for jj in range(p):
            for kk in range(n):
                out[ii * p + jj] += a[ii * n + kk] * b[kk * p + jj]
```

see `tests/run/gufunc.pyx` for more examples.

## Difference to `@cython.ufunc`
When all arguments and outputs in the signature are scalar - i.e. `ufuncs` are in principle sufficient - the `@cython.gufunc` syntax still has some notable differences to the `@cython.ufunc` syntax. Particularly as outputs are not directly returned, but rather passed in as pointers:

```python
@cython.gufunc("(),()->()")
cdef void args_int(int a1, int a2, int* out):
    out[0] = a1 + a2
```
vs.
```python
@cython.ufunc
cdef void args_int(int a1, int a2):
    return a1 + a2
```

## Possible improvements
- *Type-checking* the arguments corresponding to named dimensions
- Cast pointers to appropriately shaped arrays instead -> would avoid having to manually keep track where to put things like `out[ii * p + jj] += a[ii * n + kk] * b[kk * p + jj]`

@jan-david-fischbach 

(Minor point) One of the issues I never managed to work out a nice way to do (for `ufunc` as well) is to handle PyObjects well. I don't think your version does this either because we don't allow a pointer to `object`. I don't think there's a nice solution though, so I don't think it's a problem that needs solving here. It's also a limitation of `ufunc` with multiple return values.

I think the bigger issue with your implementation is that it assumes that all the arrays are C contiguous and that isn't generally true.
(At least I can't see any tests for it, and I think the wrapped function would have to know the steps to work).
Obvious it would be possible to add the steps to the signature too although using them to do the manual calculation of where to write would be a bit nasty.

To me that suggests that it would be better to have a function taking typed memoryviews for array arguments. That'd probably lose a little bit of performance over the raw pointer version, but it'd be much more usable.

-----------

(thanks for the AI disclosure - I think it is better to put these things up front)

Hey @da-woods ,
My primary motivation was to reduce boilerplate in our multiple-scattering library [treams](https://github.com/tfp-photonics/treams/blob/main/src%2Ftreams%2Fspecial%2F_gufuncs.pyx). There we previously also used pointer magic to define the gufuncs. 

The problem: introducing the gufunc decorator instead of the boilerplate is seen as a "cosmetic" change, that should not negatively impact performance. Maybe we could provide both options, inferring from the signature of the wrapped function whether it accepts typed memory views or pointers?

title: [ENH] Auto-generation of generalized ufuncs
